title: Week 3: January 12–18 - Genesis 1–2; Moses 2–3; Abraham 4–5
content:
# Come, Follow Me 2026: Week 3 Study Guide  
**January 12–18: Genesis 1–2; Moses 2–3; Abraham 4–5**

## Theological Framework
Imagine an earth “without form, and void” and “empty and desolate” (Genesis 1:2; Abraham 4:2). How does such chaos become a majestic world? This question unlocks the doctrinal theme of divine creation, revealing God's power to transform the unorganized into the exalted. Across dispensations, this pattern mirrors Heavenly Father's work with us: from spiritual chaos to divine potential. “Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ are Creators, and Their creative work with us is not finished. They can make light shine in dark moments in our lives. They can fill our emptiness with life. They can transform us into the divine beings we were meant to be” (CFM Introduction).

Pattern Recognition Mastery emerges in the three harmonious accounts—Genesis, Moses, Abraham—each affirming “By mine Only Begotten I created these things” (Moses 2:1; see Genesis 1:1–25; Moses 2:1–25; Abraham 4:1–25). This principle echoes from Adam's era, where creation established order, to Moses' visions, Abraham's premortal insights, and our day, where personal creation continues. We are “created in God’s image, after His likeness” (Genesis 1:26), pointing to exaltation. Stewardship over creations (Genesis 1:28) and Sabbath sanctification (Genesis 2:2–3) extend this framework, binding generations in covenantal progression toward godliness.

## Language and Literary Insights
The literary structure of these chapters builds awe through rhythmic repetition: “And God said, Let there be...” followed by divine pronouncements and separations of light from darkness, waters from waters (Genesis 1; Moses 2; Abraham 4). This poetic parallelism across accounts creates a symphony of creation periods, culminating in humanity's introduction. Key terms like “image” and “likeness” in Genesis 1:26–27; Moses 2:26–27; Abraham 4:26–27 invite pondering: not mere physical resemblance, but divine potential, male and female together.

The shift in Genesis 2; Moses 3; Abraham 5 to narrative detail—the Garden, Adam and Eve's union—contrasts the grand overview, drawing readers into intimate relational language: “It is not good that the man should be alone” (Genesis 2:18; Moses 3:18; Abraham 5:14). This structure reveals progression from cosmic order to eternal marriage, sanctified by priesthood (see Russell M. Nelson, “Lessons from Eve,” Ensign, Nov. 1987, 87). Such patterns indicate God's deliberate artistry, transforming readers' understanding of sacred physiology and purpose.

## Prophetic Patterns Across Time
Divine patterns of revelation converge strikingly: God reveals Creation through direct words to Moses (Moses 2–3), Abraham's visions (Abraham 4–5), and ancient records (Genesis 1–2). Each account unveils redemption's foundation—order from void, foreshadowing Christ's Atonement. Covenant-making begins here: dominion granted (Genesis 1:28; Moses 2:28; Abraham 4:28) as stewardship, paralleling patriarchal covenants renewed through dispensations.

This pattern indicates generational continuity: Adam and Eve's eternal marriage (Genesis 2:18–25; Abraham 5:14–18) models “marriage between a man and a woman... ordained of God” (CFM), linking to Mosaic law, Abrahamic promises, and latter-day proclamations. Sabbath rest (Genesis 2:2–3; Moses 3:2–3) patterns holy time across eras, from Eden to Sinai to our temples. Modern echoes affirm: prophets urge Sabbath-keeping as delight (see D&C 59:9–13), converging ancient pattern with today's call to holiness.

## Cross-Reference Web Matrix
These chapters weave a vast network across standard works, unveiling hidden relationships:

- **Creation Agency**: Genesis 1:1–25 → Moses 2:1–25; Abraham 4:1–25 → D&C 101:32–34 (worlds created by Christ).
- **Divine Image**: Genesis 1:26–27; Moses 2:26–27; Abraham 4:26–27 → Mosiah 3:19 (natural man opposes divine image); Ether 12:27 (weakness becomes strength in God's likeness).
- **Eternal Marriage**: Genesis 2:18–25; Moses 3:18, 21–24; Abraham 5:14–18 → 1 Corinthians 11:11 (“neither is the man without the woman”); “The Family: A Proclamation to the World.”
- **Stewardship**: Genesis 1:28; Moses 2:28; Abraham 4:28 → D&C 59:16–21 (thanksgiving for earth's bounty); D&C 104:13–18 (agency in stewardship).
- **Sabbath Sanctification**: Genesis 2:2–3; Moses 3:2–3; Abraham 5:2–3 → D&C 59:9–13 (Sabbath as delight).

This matrix reveals Creation as doctrinal hub, connecting Eden to every dispensation.

## Historical and Cultural Context
In ancient Near Eastern chaos myths, creation arose from conflict; here, God's peaceful word orders the void (Genesis 1:2; Abraham 4:2), paralleling Israel's need for order amid exile. The Garden narrative (Genesis 2; Moses 3; Abraham 5) evokes Edenic paradise, contrasting cultural polygamy or isolation with divinely ordained unity: “Adam and Eve were joined together in marriage for time and for all eternity” (Russell M. Nelson, “Lessons from Eve,” Ensign, Nov. 1987, 87).

For overview, see “Genesis” in the Bible Dictionary, framing these as foundational records preserved for covenant Israel. Such context creates “aha moments”: ancient beauties (e.g., “All Creatures of Our God and King,” Hymns, no. 62) mirror modern reverence amid creation's stewardship (D&C 59:16–21), urging discipleship in a stewardship-scarce world.

## Reconciling Difficult Passages
A tension arises: if created in God's image (Genesis 1:26–27), why imperfection? Some claim “all of our thoughts, feelings, and desires are approved by Him and that we don’t need to (or cannot) improve” (CFM). Reconciliation shines through: divine image denotes potential, not innate perfection. Mosiah 3:19 reveals the “natural man” must yield to the spiritual; Ether 12:27 promises strength through humility. Three accounts harmonize, emphasizing growth: from void to exalted (Genesis 1:2 onward).

Account variations (e.g., creation sequence) resolve in complementary witnesses—Genesis' poetic summary, Moses' doctrinal clarity, Abraham's premortal scope—uniting in Christ's creative role. This pattern indicates profound truth: unified revelation amid diversity.

## Deeper Study Notes
Ponder: “What does God teach you about it in Genesis 1:1–25; Moses 2:1–25; and Abraham 4:1–25? Why does He want you to know these things?” (CFM). Advanced pattern: seventh-day rest (Genesis 2:2–3) sanctifies time, prefiguring temple rest. For adults, map stewardship (Genesis 1:28) to D&C 104:13–18, discovering agency patterns. Use mirrors or animal likenesses (CFM children section) for sophisticated reflection: “Because I know I am created in God’s image, I choose to…” (CFM). Extract: video “God’s Greatest Creation” shifts paradigms on body's sacredness versus worldly messages.

## Teaching Applications
**Escalating Stakes Questions**:

1. **Understanding**: What parallels emerge in Genesis 1:26–27; Moses 2:26–27; Abraham 4:26–27? How do they teach about Heavenly Father, Jesus Christ, the world, and yourself? (CFM).

2. **Transformation**: When life feels “without form, and void” (Genesis 1:2), how can Creation truths “make light shine in dark moments”? Complete: “Because I am created in God’s image, I choose to…” (CFM). Role-play Sabbath explanations using Genesis 2:2–3.

3. **Testimony**: How does eternal marriage (Genesis 2:18–25) elevate your view of family? Share pictures/testimonies of creations (CFM). Sing “My Heavenly Father Loves Me” (Children’s Songbook, 228–29); discuss stewardship (D&C 59:16–21). For children: Creation searches, body puzzles.

Invite creativity: draw/build principles (Teaching in the Savior’s Way, 32).

## Modern Prophetic Convergence
Contemporary voices precisely mirror ancient revelations. President Russell M. Nelson testifies: “Adam and Eve were joined together in marriage for time and for all eternity by the power of [the] everlasting priesthood” ( “Lessons from Eve,” Ensign, Nov. 1987, 87), converging Genesis 2:18–25 with eternal doctrine. In “God’s Greatest Creation” (Gospel Library), he celebrates the body as “miraculous,” countering devaluation: “How does Heavenly Father want me to feel about my body?” (CFM). Elder Gérald Caussé echoes stewardship: “Our Earthly Stewardship” (Liahona, Nov. 2022, 57–59), aligning Genesis 1:28 with Topics “Environmental Stewardship and Conservation.”

These convergences document unchanging truth.

## Testimony Development
Deep study of these accounts forges conviction: recognizing Christ's hand in every “Let there be” awakens awe for our divine image. Patterns from Eden's order to personal transformation testify of living Creators. As I trace stewardship from Genesis 1:28 to D&C 104, gratitude swells for earth's gifts, solidifying faith in covenants. This pattern recognition builds unshakeable trust: God, who sanctified the Sabbath (Genesis 2:2–3), invites us to holy rest, promising exaltation.

## Additional Study
Explore bundle resources: “The Sabbath Is a Delight” (video); “God’s Greatest Creation” (President Nelson); Old Testament Stories, “The Creation of the Earth” (8–12); For the Strength of Youth, “Your body is sacred” (22–29); Liahona/For the Strength of Youth/Friend magazines; “The Family: A Proclamation to the World”; Bible Dictionary “Genesis”; Hymns no. 62; Children’s Songbook 228–29; pictures (Garden of Eden by Grant Romney Clawson; The Creation by Annie Henrie Nader). Venture outdoors among creations for pattern immersion (CFM).
